text: testified as follows:
- - - EXAMINATION
Could you state your full name for the record, please?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: James Farr, F-A-R-R.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Farr, my name is Joseph Blum and I represent Mercedes-Benz in a case that's been brought by Capitol Indemnity Insurance. I'm going to ask you a series of questions today about what you might know about that incident or the aftermath of that incident. If at any time you don't understand my question, please let me know, I'll be happy to restate it for you.  And I would ask that you keep all of your responses verbal because the court reporter cannot take down nods of our heads or shrugs of our shoulders.  Okay?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I would also ask you to try to let me finish stating my question before you start to speak so that the court reporter also can take us each down separately.  Okay?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Could you tell us by whom you're employed?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The Johns Eastern Company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what does Johns Eastern Company do?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: We are an independent insurance adjusting firm.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you do work for insureds or for the insurance industry or both?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The insurance industry.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And how long have you worked there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: 15-1/2 years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what do you do there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Currently I'm a field adjuster supervisor.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And how long have you been in that position?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Six to seven years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And tell me, what does that mean?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As opposed to going into the field any longer, I supervise those who do go into the field and review their product before being released to the insurance carriers and clients.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And do you do any adjusting at all yourself at this point or --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Minimal.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And are there certain types of claims that you handle personally?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Not at this point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I mean, on occasion I still do go out.  But usually it's because volume is up or staffing is low.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And before you became the supervisor, what were you doing?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Field adjusting.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is this all property damage claims?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So tell me the varieties, the types of claims that you would be working on?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: We do first-party property, third-party property, which is what I supervise at this point, but I'm also trained and experienced with casualty, slip and falls, trip and falls, both commercial and homeowner.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And before you went to your current employer, who did you work for?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Allstate Insurance.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did you work at Allstate?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: About four years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you do there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Auto adjuster, auto -- yeah, auto adjuster.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And before Allstate where did you work?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Grotto Pizza.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And was that something you did while you were in school or right out of school?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Since I was 15 until I married my wife and couldn't get her a job up there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And tell us what your educational background is?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I have a Bachelor of Arts degree, major in criminal justice from Lycoming College, Williamsport.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what year did you get that degree?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: And while you were at Allstate, did you receive any type of formal training there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And just tell us basically what kind of training you received from them?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Sent me to Chicago to a training center that they had out there at their home office that included claim setup, initial contact, and just liability investigations, auto liability investigations.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And when you went to Johns Eastern, have you received any formal training there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Formal, not through Johns Eastern.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Through any other source?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I am half a course shy of my AIC exam through The Institutes.  Other than that, that's --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What would that stand for?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Associate in claims.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is that something you are continuing to work towards?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.  My final exam is next week, two weeks.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you have to go somewhere to take those courses or is it online?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I study online.  And then a course is taken or the test is taken at PerlMetrics.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And any other training that you received since you've been at Johns Eastern?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: We just finished up a training seminar for independent appraisals and independent umpires.  I have been trained with NFIP flood insurance, my license has lapsed though, because we just don't have the opportunity. I have my Delaware license for adjustment along with reciprocating licenses for most of New England, Maine, New Hampshire, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Massachusetts doesn't require one.  And I do not license in New York.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How about Pennsylvania, do they require one?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: They do not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At some point was your company assigned a loss that occurred at S-Bond Technologies in Lansdale?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Can you tell me what your personal involvement was with that claim?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I was the assigned field adjuster to adjust for business personal property loss.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you have anything to do with any type of what I'll call business interruption or extra expense claims?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Minimal.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was forwarded on to someone else.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was your minimal involvement with that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Early on before it got separated out, I collected information to set up a new office, such as installation of new phone systems, security systems, IT department for a new location.  Had our IT supervisor review some of the documents for additional loss expense.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: But then it was eventually moved on to someone when it came into business income loss as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you personally, when this assignment came in, go out to the premises?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And who, if anyone, did you meet there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I remember Ron Smith was there.  I do not recall anyone else's name.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is it accurate that you were there acting on behalf of Capitol Indemnity Insurance?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe we referred to them as Capitol Specialty, but yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was the assignment, like what officially did they ask you to do?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't recall, so I apologize.  But for the most part I would probably say they, "Here's an assignment, please go out and review and report.  And we'll go from there as to what we need next." It's usually, "Let's set a reserve, let's find a cause of loss, if determinable, and then appraise damages."
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what, if anything, did you do to prepare for your deposition today?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I tried to review my file as best as possible.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And tell me your files, are they maintained in paper or electronic?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Electronic.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it something that's maintained on a server in your office or elsewhere?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Online.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And tell me, how is that file organized on your computer system, what does it look like?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Per file, so you search per our individual file numbers, and then when it's opened up, individual documents are titled in a list.  And then we can open up individual documents for review of said document.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  So it's not like when you open it up, there's subfolders that have different categories or anything like that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I would not call them subfolders, no.  It's one, here is all the documents for your file in a list, but then you have to choose which one you actually want to view.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: You have to make sure they're titled properly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And other than reviewing your file, did you do anything else other than speak to Gus?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there anybody at Capitol Indemnity that you reached out to about you being asked to be here for a deposition?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Just to provide knowledge to Paul Petrovich.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you had an opportunity to review any of the deposition transcripts for anyone who has been deposed here in this case?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You mentioned that one of the things that you were asked to do was determine the cause of the loss.  Did you do that in this case?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I did not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why not?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was too large of a loss, too complicated, so an outside vendor was retained to finish that portion of it off.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And do you know who that was?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I apologize, I do not recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Not a problem. And did you ever ask Mr. -- is it Ron Smith?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, the named insured owner of S-Bond.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you ever ask him if he had any knowledge of how the fire started?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe, if I recall, during our initial inspection, it had started in a neighboring unit of the building, and there was rumors and speculation that it may have been one of the vehicles parked inside the building.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you do anything to verify any of those rumors or speculation?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.  It was turned over to whoever the cause and origin investigator was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you know what was the first day that you went out there to investigate this loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I would have to check my notes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Why don't we stop for a minute then.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (Short recess.)
Mr. Farr, you were kind enough to bring with you portions of your file.  Can you tell us, is there any portion of your file that you did not bring with you?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what is it you did not bring?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Reports, the specific interim reports.  And various email exchanges between the insured and myself, between myself and Cap Specialty.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Which I believe were produced in some fashion.
speaker: MR. SARA

text: I'm just trying to figure out what I have and don't have.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: You have it all in some fashion.
speaker: MR. SARA

text: What I brought was my adjustment and supports for said adjustments.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay, perfect. We are going to mark, if we could, as Exhibit 1 a portion of your file, and ask you if you could first identify for us what that is.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (90-page photo report, no Bates numbers, marked Farr Exhibit 1.)
This is a printout of the photographs I took during my initial inspection.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And is this all of the photographs you took during your initial inspection?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I want to say no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: But they are the ones that I utilized.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And in what manner did you utilize them?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Ones I wouldn't use would be the duplicate photographs that would have shown the same thing, a photograph that would not have come out clearly.  It just would have been not included in my photo report.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And in this, as you called it, photo report, does this, as far as you're concerned, document all of the items on which the insured made a claim?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't think that it is supposed to be in there, but it looks like it just -- off the record.
speaker: MR. SARA

text: (Discussion off the record.)
(The court reporter read the record as follows:  "And in this, as you called it, photo report, does this, as far as you're concerned, document all of the items on which the insured made a claim?")

It is my effort, it was my effort to document all of the items that the insured made a claim for. There are several overview shots of items.  Did I take photographs of each individual specific items?  No.  But in a overview shot they were located during submission of lists from the insured.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  The very first page appears to be a cover page.  Is that basically providing just all the background information about who contacts were and everything?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Exactly.  It's just a setup.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At the bottom of this it says, "Date inspected:  6/17/2016."  Is that the day you recall being there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That would be accurate, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Can you tell us on June 17th when you went there what you did?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was an informal interview with the insured, walk-through of the property, walk-around of the property, photographs, and note-taking.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you say note-taking, can you tell us what kind of notes you took?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Handwritten notes of our conversation for memoriam.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you keep those handwritten notes?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't recall at this point.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I'm going to show you some documents which you provided, which I believe are inventories which came from the client.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: We'll mark this as Exhibit 2, please.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (S-Bond Replacement Expenses, with attached documents, no Bates numbers, marked Farr Exhibit 2.)
Mr. Farr, could you tell us first, what is Exhibit 2?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Exhibit 2 appears to be the second business personal property inventory list provided by the insured, along with copies of his purchase receipts for replacement of those items that were damaged in the loss.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Let me see if I can -- is this one the first?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It is not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Maybe that one, the thinner one --
speaker: MR. SARA

text: That one.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let's mark this as Exhibit No. 3, if we could.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (S-Bond Replacement Cost Request, no Bates numbers, marked Farr Exhibit 3.)
All right.  Mr. Farr, showing you Exhibit No. 3, is this the first inventory that's a document that came from S-Bond?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: This looks like the first list, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you received this first list, what, if anything, did you do with it?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Reviewed it and requested additional information for it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So let's just take one of the items, like at the very top it says "Honeywell Portable Air Cooler."  Is all the information that appears for that unit there information that was put in by the insured?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe, yes, it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And tell me, what was your understanding of the difference between the replacement cost estimate and the cost columns?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Replacement cost would be what it cost him to replace it today versus what he purchased it for.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So the replacement cost estimate is what you think he paid for it originally and then the cost is what he -- or just the opposite?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Opposite.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you went through this list, did you approve these items for payment by the insurance company?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I eventually did approve them, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And which number did you approve?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: If I were to guess, I would have to check my report number 8 list there, but I would say it was the $19,972.69.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then is it accurate that the insured was reimbursed for the replacement cost versus the actual cash value on these items?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Although I did not issue the check, that would be my presumption.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Let me ask you this.  Did you personally or anyone on your behalf make an attempt to determine the actual cash value on any of these items?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you receive backup invoices from the insured for everything that was listed on Exhibit No. 3?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: My guess was it was requested. However, I was unable to locate it in my file.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you report to Capitol Indemnity, does it require you to send them copies of all the invoices or just your report?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.  I send them everything.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Let's go back now to Exhibit No. 2, I think, which I already marked, which I believe you said was the second inventory; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe it is, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And again -- I'm sorry, on this Exhibit No. 2, again, this information all came from the insured; correct?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It did, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in the column that says "Status" there is listed RP there.  Did you have an understanding of what that meant?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe it was his code for replaced.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And so then is it accurate that only the things that he replaced he was paid for?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So some of the items, for example, like if you go partway down, there's a whole bunch of items for Kobalt tools and tool cabinet.  Are those like a new item?  Can you tell me why those are listed if they're not being replaced?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Receipt number 23, which shows that they were replaced.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So I'm a little bit confused about why the RP is there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I didn't fill the form out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  Again, I know that, so it's just a question of what your understanding was?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: As I talked to him, if I recall, he told me that RP meant replaced.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And again, was it your understanding that the insured was being reimbursed for the replacement cost and not the actual cash value on these items?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: That was my understanding, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you personally undertake, make any attempt to determine what the actual cash value was on any of these?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you personally try to connect the things that are listed on Exhibit 2 or 3 to the photographs that you had of the loss?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you verify to your satisfaction that everything that was on Exhibit 2 and 3 was actually there at the property and damaged?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Let me show you a document which we'll mark as Exhibit 4.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (S-Bond Replacement Items/ Expenses, with attached documents, no Bates numbers, marked Farr Exhibit 4.)
Is Exhibit No. 4 what I'll call the next group of requests by the insured?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.  This would be his third list.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And did you personally verify that all of these items were actually in the property?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Through review of my photographs is how it was done, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And here on the column that says "Status," there's one of the items that has CL next to it.  Do you see that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have an understanding of what the CL stood for?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: My understanding was cleaned.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: But I don't know the final status. Receipt would suggest that they were repurchased again, cleaning did not sufficiently clean beakers, chemicals, graduated cylinders.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And your position would be if we look for receipt number 66 in the backup behind this, that would show those items?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes, as I recall it should.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And if you in fact turn to -- they're numbered at the top, is that correct, the invoices?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: All right.  And this is the replacement cost for those beakers?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It's what I was told.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  It doesn't appear that the math actually adds up, though, does it?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: U/S cleaner supplies.  It looks like Line 1 of that estimate would have been subtracted out of the total to provide the final total of the $58.86.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in fact if you look at that, are in fact those -- they're not replacement items, they're actually items to clean?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Which is what his list says, U/S cleaner supplies, and then I would have to assume that glass beakers, chemicals, graduated cylinders is what he was cleaning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And as far as you know, the insured was reimbursed for the total that appears here?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I believe he was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And there is an item on this particular list for demolition and excavation at the old address.  Do you see that?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was the insured responsible for some form of demo at the property?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: A portion of it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what were they responsible for?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: My guess is the invoice that has yet to be reviewed yet.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: We'll mark this as Exhibit 5.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: (Group of documents, no Bates numbers, marked Farr Exhibit 5.)
I'm showing you Exhibit 5, and it looks to me that there's actually two -- several things that are combined here.  Why don't you go through and tell us what each of these items is?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: The first one was the demolition bid of his portion of the total billing demolition.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: He left several items inside of it that needed to be carted away.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: And that was his portion of the total demo from Knechel. The second one, EDS, is a packout of salvageable items and storage at an offsite facility.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: And the third one is their final invoice, I believe.  The $1,570 would be their final invoice for moving van back to a new location. Next one would be a Power ER invoice for the computers, replacement and -- well, it was inspection and diagnostic of computers and computer equipment along with replacement.

text: And was Power ER somebody that you recommended or hired or somebody they recommended or hired?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was a contractor the insured was comfortable with using --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: -- so we worked with them to review.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: There's next the photographs of said computers. Next appears to be the telephone system replacement of which they upgraded a conference phone, so it was eliminated from the list.

text: Okay.  That's the Ironman Consulting invoice?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It is, yes.  Dated July 24th. There's a second one from Ironman, I believe it's for, looks like configuration of the firewall, 500 gigabyte storage unit. Then we have proposal for the -- I believe this was the security system.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So --
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: From CzarStar Security.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So they had a security system at the old facility?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is this going into the temporary facility or their new permanent facility?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I don't recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And do you know whether or not they had any type of fire alarms or smoke detectors or anything like that in the old facility?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I would have to review again.  But I don't recall at this time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Why don't you keep going ahead.  I'm sorry to interrupt.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: This looks like this is actually inventory list number 4.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you say inventory list number 4, just so the record is clear, it's the one that has October 1 through December 15 of 2016?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It is.  It got pinched in with the invoices.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And again, did you review this inventory list number 4 to verify that all this equipment was there?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: I would have similarly to the rest of them, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And other than receiving the receipts from the insured, did you do anything to verify the cost that they were setting forth?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: It was review of the receipts.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: And validating.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was there any attempt to identify the actual cash value of any of the items that are listed on that inventory?
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: No.

text: Okay.  You can put that one back together, actually.
speaker: MR. BLUM

text: Okay.

text: I'm going to now show you a document which we'll mark as Exhibit No. 6, which that is listed as the Master List of Scrapped Items, and ask you if you can tell us what that is, please?

text: Economically unsalvageable, not worth anything -- I wouldn't say not worth anything, but just of no value -- or comparison to clean versus replacement versus keeping just didn't make sense to the insured. While they were still in use, I was told that, for an example, he had four power drills, I don't recall, but let's say he had four power drills, he only really needs two anymore.  All four power drills worked and were used, but he really only needs two anymore.  So that's where he would scrap two of them.
